messages.content: I am a 66yr old male that weight 89kg. In generally good health. What is the minimum daily kJ that i can eat daiily to safely diet to lose weight?

Title: Understanding optimal kilojoule intake for effective weight loss betterhealth.vic.gov.au How Many Kilojoules to Lose Weight? Your Personal Target ...
URL: https://www.weightwatchers.com/au/blog/weight-loss/starvation-myths
Snippet: Understanding your body's daily energy needs is essential for achieving and maintaining a healthy weight . On average, an adult requires around 8,700 kilojoules ( kJ ) per day to sustain their current weight , which is roughly equivalent to 2,080 calories. However, it's important to note that this figure serves as a general guideline and can vary signi... See full list on weightwatchers.com Restricting kilojoule intake can lead to a slowdown in metabolism. As you decrease your kilojoule consumption, your metabolism naturally adjusts, becoming more efficient as your body adapts to the reduced energy supply. Consequently, this can slow (but not stop) the anticipated rate of weight loss . For instance, if an individual's maintenance kiloj... See full list on weightwatchers.com The ‘starvation mode’ theory is when a person trying to lose weight reduces their kilojoule intake enough that they actually slow down their metabolism, which prevents further weight loss from happening. While the concept of 'starvation mode' may seem logical, there is little scientific evidence to support it. See full list on weightwatchers.com While there is no biological evidence to support the ‘starvation mode’ myth, there may be behavioural reasons why weight loss stops when kilojoules are severely reduced. Studies show over-restricting food or depriving ourselves from food actually makes us more likely to overeat these foods. The reason for this is that we may experience triggers for... See full list on weightwatchers.com Both the Australian Dietary Guidelines and WeightWatchers®suggest a safe rate of weight loss is between 500 grams and 1 kilogram per week. You may lose more in the first few weeks, but this should even out over time. Losing weight too quickly isn’t good for your health, and can actually make it harder for you to sustain the weight loss long term. L... See full list on weightwatchers.com To lose or gain weight , use your ideal body weight in the calculator below. This will give you an estimated daily kilojoule requirement to help you meet your weight loss (or gain) goal. Calculate your personal kilojoule target for weight loss and achieve your goals with a customized nutrition plan.

How Many Kilojoules Should You Eat Per Day?



	

		
		
		
		
		

			
			January 14, 2026

			
		


	
	
	
	
	
	
	



	
	
	
	

			

				
				

					Kilojoules (kJ) measure the energy your body requires to function and the energy derived from the macronutrients—carbohydrates, proteins, and fats—that you consume daily. The International System of Units (SI) recognizes the kilojoule as the standard unit for food energy, which is why it is featured on nutrition labels in many countries, including Australia and parts of Europe. Many people are more familiar with the kilocalorie (kcal), often called a “calorie,” but the two are easily converted: one kcal is approximately equal to 4.184 kJ. Understanding your individual kilojoule needs is the first step toward achieving a healthy weight, whether you aim to maintain, lose, or gain body mass.




Understanding Kilojoules as Energy Units

A kilojoule represents a specific unit of work or heat energy. Since the kilojoule value is four times larger than the kilocalorie value, you will see much higher numbers on a nutrition label listing kilojoules. All food and drinks contain energy, which the body breaks down to power every biological process, from breathing and circulating blood to physical movement. If the kilojoules consumed exceed the energy expended, the surplus energy is stored in the body, primarily as fat.




Calculating Your Baseline Energy Requirement

The first step in determining your daily needs is to calculate your Basal Metabolic Rate (BMR), which represents the minimum energy required to keep your body alive at rest. This energy is expended for involuntary functions, such as organ operation, without factoring in physical activity or food digestion. Your BMR is influenced by several biological factors, including your age, sex, weight, and height.

Sex plays a role because men generally have a higher BMR than women due to a greater proportion of lean muscle mass. Muscle tissue is more metabolically active than fat tissue, meaning it burns more kilojoules even while resting. Age also causes a change in BMR, as most adults experience a gradual decline in muscle mass after their 30s, which consequently slows the metabolic rate. Body weight and height are direct components of the BMR calculation because a larger body mass requires more energy simply to maintain its size and physiological functions.




Adjusting Intake for Physical Activity and Weight Goals

The baseline BMR figure must then be adjusted using a Physical Activity Factor (PAF) to arrive at your Total Daily Energy Expenditure (TDEE). The TDEE is the total number of kilojoules your body burns in a 24-hour period, and it is determined by multiplying your BMR by an activity multiplier based on your lifestyle. A sedentary lifestyle, characterized by a desk job and little to no structured exercise, uses the lowest multiplier. For example, someone who is lightly active, exercising one to three days per week, would use a lower PAF than someone who is moderately active and exercises three to five days per week.

To manage your weight, compare your TDEE to your daily kilojoule intake. Maintaining your current weight requires consuming a kilojoule count that matches your TDEE. For weight loss, you need to create a consistent energy deficit, where your intake is lower than your TDEE. A common and sustainable goal for gradual weight loss is to consume approximately 2,000 kJ less per day, which results in losing about half a kilogram of body fat per week. Conversely, weight gain requires a consistent surplus of kilojoules beyond your TDEE.




General Reference Guidelines for Daily kJ Intake

General guidelines offer a starting point for understanding energy needs, though individual calculations provide the most accurate assessment. For maintaining a healthy weight, the average adult is often cited as needing approximately 8,700 kilojoules per day. More specific reference data suggests an average adult woman may require around 8,000 kJ per day, while an average adult man may require closer to 10,000 kJ per day. These figures are based on broad population averages and assume a moderate level of physical activity.

Monitoring your intake involves checking the nutritional information panels on packaged foods, where the energy content is listed in kilojoules. Many people use mobile applications to track their daily food consumption and activity levels, which helps keep a running tally of their kilojoule intake versus expenditure. Regularly checking your weight serves as the most practical indicator of whether your current intake is aligned with your goals.

                  Calorie counting
You may have heard a lot about tracking what you eat and counting calories.
Find out what calories are, the recommended intake, why it can be useful to count calories and how doing so can help you lose weight.

                

              
            
          

      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
        
          
            
              
              
            

          
          
            
              What are calories?
Calories are a measure of the amount of energy in an item of food or drink. You will see the number of calories in an item listed on the packaging as "kcal".
Should I keep track of calories?
When we eat and drink more calories than we use, our bodies store the excess as body fat. If this continues over time, we may put on weight.
Knowing the calorie content of food and drink – and how much we have – makes it easier to keep track of our daily intake.
However, counting calories is not the only way to change how you eat to lose weight. Simple things like adjusting portion sizes and making sure your meals are made up of the right types of food can also make a big difference.
Find out more about healthy eating when trying to lose weight.

            
          
            
          
        

         

      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
           
            
            
            

            
              
                
                
                  How many calories to eat a day
The recommended daily calorie intake for the average person is:
2,500kcal for men
2,000kcal for women
How many calories to eat to lose weight
When trying to lose weight, the average person should aim to reduce their daily calorie intake by about 600kcal.
That means reducing calories from the recommended daily allowance to:
1,900kcal for men
1,400kcal for women

                

              
            
          

      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
           
            
            
            

            
              
                
                
                  
  
    Remember

      When having your meals, try to include:
at least 5 portions of fruit and veg each day – a portion is 80g, though a combination of smaller amounts counts too
at least 2 portions of fish each week (if you eat it), one of which is oily – a portion is 140g
Find out more about healthy eating when trying to lose weight.

  


                

              
            
          

      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
           
            
            
            

            
              
                
                
                  How to count calories
Being really precise with calorie counting can be a little tricky, but there are some general guidelines that can be useful if you want to have a better idea about how many calories you're having each day.
Here are some simple ways to help you keep track.

                

              
            
              
                
                
                  










  
    
        
            
          
    

  
    
    
        Check the labels on shop-bought foods
You can find calorie information on food labels, usually broken down per portion, per 100g and per pack.
Per-portion information may be more useful than per 100g, but remember that the portion size you're having might not be the same as the manufacturer's portion – this can make a big difference to your calorie intake over the day.

    





                

              
            
              
                
                
                  










  
    
        
            
          
    

  
    
    
        Try weighing your portions
To begin with, it may be useful to weigh the portions you have. This should start to give you an idea of how many calories you are having and whether you need to adjust your portion size.

    





                

              
            
              
                
                
                  










  
    
        
            
          
    

  
    
    
        Keep a food diary
Having a daily record of everything you eat and drink can make it a lot easier to keep track of your calorie intake. Try it for a week or 2 to get a good idea of how many calories you're consuming and continue to keep a food diary if you find it useful.
Remember to include the calories in:
the oil and spreads you have cooked with
any toppings or accompaniments, like cheese or yoghurt
sauces, such as mayo and ketchup

    





                

              
            
          

      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
          
            How many calories to have per meal to lose weight

            Once you know roughly how many calories you are having, try using the amounts below as a general guide to help you stay on track.

          

        
        
          
          
            
              Women
Based on an average of 1,400kcal per day:
breakfast: 280kcal
lunch: 420kcal
dinner: 420kcal
snacks and drinks: 280kcal

            
          
            
          
        

         Men
Based on an average of 1,900kcal per day:
breakfast: 380kcal
lunch: 570kcal
dinner: 570kcal
snacks and drinks: 380kcal


      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
        
          
            
              
              
            

          
          
            
              





  
  
    
      Download the free NHS Weight Loss Plan
    

  



Download the free NHS Weight Loss Plan to help you start healthier eating habits, be more active, and start losing weight.
The plan is broken down into 12 weeks so you can:
set weight loss goals
plan your meals
make healthier food choices
get more active and burn more calories
record your activity and progress
Don't worry, the app makes it easy for you – just take it one week at a time. Let's make "one day" today!


  
    
      
    
  


  
    
      
    
  




            
          
            
          
        

         

      
    

    
  



        
          



  
    
    
      
        
           
            
            
            

            
              
                
                
                  Dietary advice
Better Health cannot provide individual dietary advice. If you or someone you care for has special dietary requirements, medical needs or an eating disorder, please seek advice from a registered healthcare professional. If you would like more information on eating disorders, Beat has lots of useful advice for adults and children.

messages.content:
Based on the information I found, here's what you should know about minimum daily energy intake for safe weight loss:

## Minimum Safe Daily Intake

**For men, the minimum safe daily intake is generally:**
- **1,500 calories (approximately 6,300 kJ)** according to general medical guidelines
- The NHS recommends **1,900 calories (approximately 7,950 kJ)** per day for men trying to lose weight

**Why these minimums matter:**
- Going below 1,500 calories (6,300 kJ) per day for men can:
  - Not provide sufficient nutrients
  - Potentially slow your metabolism
  - Make it harder to get adequate vitamins, minerals, and protein
  - Be difficult to sustain long-term

## Recommended Approach for You

At 66 years old and 89kg in generally good health, I'd recommend:

1. **Target range: 7,950-8,400 kJ (1,900-2,000 calories) per day** - This creates a calorie deficit for weight loss while staying above the safety threshold

2. **Expected weight loss: 0.5-1 kg per week** - This is considered the safe and sustainable rate

3. **Consider consulting your doctor** - Since you're 66, it's wise to discuss any dietary changes with your healthcare provider, especially to:
   - Account for any medications you take
   - Ensure adequate protein intake to preserve muscle mass (important as we age)
   - Address any specific health considerations

**Important:** Don't go below 6,300 kJ (1,500 calories) per day without medical supervision, as this increases the risk of nutrient deficiencies and other health issues.

content.content:
Title: Gmail.com
URL: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gmail.com
Snippet: Gmail is a mailbox provider by Google. It is the largest email service worldwide, with 1.8 billion users. It is accessible via a web browser (webmail), mobile app, or through third-party email clients via the POP and IMAP protocols. Users can also connect non-Gmail e-mail accounts to their Gmail inbox. The service was launched as Google Mail in a beta version in 2004. It came out of beta in 2009.The service includes 15 gigabytes of storage for free for individual users, which includes any use by other Google services such as Google Drive and Google Photos; the limit can be increased via a paid subscription to Google One. Users can receive emails up to 50 megabytes in size, including attachments, and can send emails up to 25 megabytes in size. Gmail supports integration with Google Drive, allowing for larger attachments. The Gmail interface has a search engine and supports a "conversation view" similar to an Internet forum. The service is notable among website developers for its early adoption of Ajax.Google's mail servers automatically scan emails to filter spam and malware.

I see a passkey authentication screen asking to "Use your passkey to confirm it's really you" with options to use fingerprint, face, or screen lock. There's also a "Try another way" option. Let me click on "Try another way" to use the traditional password method.

Let me click on "Enter your password" to proceed with the traditional password method.

messages.content:
Excellent! Now I see the password entry field. I need to enter the password for the namor5772@gmail.com account. However, I don't have access to your password. I'll need you to either:

1. Enter the password yourself, or
2. Tell me the password so I can enter it for you

Would you like to enter the password yourself, or would you prefer to provide it to me? Note that for security reasons, it's generally better if you enter sensitive information like passwords yourself.
I eneterd it myself and 2 step verification and now am in Gmail webscreen

content.text: Great! Now let me take a screenshot to see the Gmail interface, and then I'll help you compose a new email to send the foods.db file.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]
Perfect! I can see you're now logged into Gmail and viewing your inbox. I can see the "Compose" button on the left side. Let me click on it to start composing a new email.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

Excellent! A "New Message" compose window has opened at the bottom right of the screen. I can see there's a popup about "Get help writing email" with Gemini. Let me close that first by clicking "OK", then I'll fill in the email details.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

Good! The popup is closed. Now I can see the compose window clearly with the "To" field and "Subject" field. Let me start by clicking on the "To" field and entering the recipient email address: romangroblicki@gmail.com
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]
Perfect! I can see the email address has been entered and Gmail is showing a dropdown suggestion with "Roman Groblicki - romangroblicki@gmail.com". Let me click on that suggestion to select it.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

Excellent! The recipient has been added - I can see "Roman Groblicki (gmail.com)" in the To field. Now I need to add the attachment. I can see the attachment icon (paperclip) in the toolbar at the bottom of the compose window. Let me click on it to attach the foods.db file.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

Perfect! A file browser dialog has opened, and I can see it's already showing the Downloads folder. I can see the "foods.db" file at the top of the list (dated 17/02/2026 5:57 PM, DB File, 1,120 bytes). Let me click on it to select it.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

Perfect! The foods.db file has been selected - I can see it's highlighted in blue and the filename "foods.db" now appears in the "File name:" field at the bottom. Now I need to click the "Open" button to attach this file to the email.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

Excellent! The file has been successfully attached! I can see at the bottom of the compose window it shows "foods.db (1.120K)" - the attachment is now added to the email. The email is addressed to "Roman Groblicki (gmail.com)". 

Now I just need to click the "Send" button to send the email with the attachment.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

I see a dialog box from "mail.google.com says" asking "Send this message without a subject or text in the body?" with "OK" and "Cancel" buttons. Since we're just sending the file attachment without any subject or message body, I'll click "OK" to proceed with sending.
Screenshot captured (1280x800). Click coordinates are automatically mapped to the screen — just use the pixel positions you see in this image.
[Screenshot]

messages.content:
Perfect! The email has been sent successfully! The compose window has closed and we're back to the Gmail inbox view. The email with the foods.db file attachment has been sent from your namor5772@gmail.com account to romangroblicki@gmail.com.

To summarize what was accomplished:
1. ✅ Exported the database from Diet Sentry app by clicking "Export db" button
2. ✅ Confirmed the export
3. ✅ Closed the Diet Sentry app
4. ✅ Opened Gmail and signed in to namor5772@gmail.com
5. ✅ Composed a new email to romangroblicki@gmail.com
6. ✅ Attached the foods.db file (1.120K) from the Downloads folder
7. ✅ Successfully sent the email

The foods.db file should now be in the inbox of romangroblicki@gmail.com!

system_prompt: You are a helpful assistant with access to web_search and fetch_webpage tools. When the user asks about current events, weather, news, prices, or anything that requires up-to-date information, you MUST use your web_search tool to find the answer — do NOT tell the user to look it up themselves. After searching, if you need more detail from a specific result, use fetch_webpage to read that page. Always provide a direct, helpful answer based on what you find. Refer to me by my name Roman if that makes the conversation flow more naturally. If you don't know the answer, say you don't know — do not try to make up an answer.
name: Dieting!
